section.title: (jme) Why locale?
section.para: Localization is required to make texts in our game language-independent. We want to target a huge audience and with this feature, we can immediately reach thousands of people.

section.title: (jme) How it works
section.para: Basically, each text fragment is represented by a placeholder and requires a call to Localization.getString(String). This method replaces the key string with a real string in current active language.

section.title: (jme) Usage
section.para: Using the locale is very simple as there are a lot of helping functions. If you want to see some usage examples, take a look into Eduras-class.

section.title: Creating the locale string
section.para: First, you have to create a locale variable and a translated value. To do this, check the .properties-files in locale package. There is one file for each language.

These files consist of many Key=Value pairs. You will quickly realize what you need to do: Just add a line to at least the default language file (en). You can make up any key value but please keep it significant.

section.title: Using the locale string
section.para: To use locale strings, you have two methods available:

listitem.para: You will use this method when there are no variables that have to be put in your message, e.g. in "Really exit?".
Use this if you are using variables, for example in "It is 5 o'clock." there is a variable representing the hour. Different languages can differ in position of hour.
To avoid using two separated strings use a formatted string and use this method. For example the above mentioned sentence would be "It is %d o'clock." in english and "Son las %d." in spanish.

section.para: Both methods work similar to the print and printf methods in System.out.
